node.title: computeContactForce in MechanicalContactConstraint cannot be overridden
node.bodyText: I want to have my own implementation of the function 'computeContactForce' in 'MechanicalContactConstraint' class. However, this function is not a virtual function. So, I cannot override it in the derived class. Most of the other functions in this class are virtual. Is there a reason why 'computeContactForce' is not a virtual function? If this could be made a virtual function, it will be helpful in further development of this constraint class.

@lindsayad and @bwspenc wrote this function.
I would say make a pull request to make it virtual if you need it
yea, feel free to make a PR

node.title: Restart simulation
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am running some simulations which takes some time to end and for this I am using a remote computer that shuts down at some times, I tried to restart these simulations from the point where it breaks with the "recovery option" but this latest did not work. Is there any command that allows me to restart the simulations from the last calculated timestep?
Thanks,
Nour

Hello
recovery using a checkpoint file is the prime way to do this.
The second option is to use a SolutionUserObject but it takes more steps
What error did you get?
Guillaume

Hello,
As far as I understood, I need to add this lines to my input file:
[Outputs]
checkpoint = true
[]
if this is true what should be the command to restart it from the timestep where it stopped after?
Thanks,
Nour

That s true
there s a doc page on restart and recover
You ll want to set the restart_file_base in the Problem block or use —recover on the command line with the name of the folder with recover datat

Hi,
I have tried to use what you recommended (out_cp file was created), but I think I missed something that I am not aware of somewhere (I followed instructions on the restart and recovery page) which is giving me the error below.

--recover needs a follow up argument with the name of the folder with the checkpoint file
the error message will update to show you what folder it s trying to open

I tried to do so, but I am still having error messages, I tried with two syntaxes since I am not sure which one should be used:
First : (with -i after recover)


Second(without -i)

what does ls return in the directory?

node.title: Conda vs HPC MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Our HPC was updating its OS and some of the packages were not working properly. So, we were using conda version of MOOSE. Recently, I installed HPC version of MOOSE once all packages were working properly on the new HPC OS. I did a quick comparison of both versions of MOOSE and I got following results:
Test File: grain_growth_2D_graintracker.i
Case 1:
Number of steps: 100
Number of cores:64
Total time:
Conda MOOSE:
real         11m57.556s
HPC MOOSE
real         4m59.171s
Case 2:
Next, I disabled adaptivity and uniform refine option and changed nx and ny from 44 to 1000. Everything else is same as Case 1. The performance is as follows
Total time:
Conda MOOSE
real         18m15.600s
HPC MOOSE
real         12m17.326s
What is your opinion about these results?
Also, I was running multiple simulation with conda version of MOOSE and I used shell script for this. Interestingly, some simulations crashed and core.* files were generated. I did not face this issue with the HPC version of MOOSE.

Hello
your conda version of MOOSE is not using an MPI compiler that is optimizing or even compiled for your HPC infrastructure. The libmesh and petsc packages are compiled in an almost-architecture-agnostic manner
This is why you loose so much performance by using conda over HPC
wrt to adaptivity vs large grid, adaptivity is more efficient if it enables you to use less elements
Guillaume

I have another question related to HPC MOOSE performance.
Is there any benefit if I use this petsc option ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh --with-64-bit-indices CXXOPTFLAGS=-g -O3 COPTFLAGS=-g -O3 FOPTFLAGS=-g -O3 ?

-g is for debugging, -03 is for optimizing. These arent really aligned goals. The debug flags are already included for the debug build
The optimization flags are hard-coded at o2 in libmesh currently. PETSc at o3 could be faster, I have not tried

node.title: Mamba Update moose-dev=2023.09.15
node.bodyText:
A recent version of our moose-dev Conda package has been made available.
mamba update --all is usually all that is necessary to update to our latest Conda packages. Sometimes however, Conda needs that extra "just do it" kick:
mamba activate moose
mamba install moose-dev=2023.09.15
Afterwards, if you have not already done so, please update your MOOSE repository, as the two are always closely tied to each other.
Moving forwards, this pinned discussion will always mention the latest available moose-dev package version a user should be operating on.
Thank you very much for this solution. Now peacock is working smoothly on my local mac machine.

node.title: Coupling Concentration Variable "c" to Charge Conservation
node.bodyText:
Hello,
In my PF simulation, the state variable concentration, c(x,y,z,t) is one parameter necessary for computing electrical conductivity.
Electrical conductivity shows up in charge conservation, where I use the HeatConduction kernel and the diffusion_coefficient is established by either a constant in the kernel or in Material using electrical_conductivity.
Can I define an expression including c directly in the HeatConduction or do I need a custom kernel that provides the coupling? This would be similar to using expression and coupled_variables in Materials but directly in the HeatConduction kernel.
Thank you.
John Sevic

You could either modify HeatConduction or create your own kernel. If you are coupling in a variable you'd want to make sure that gets into the Jacobian and currently HeatConduction only implements a Jacobian on-diagonal

OK thanks, so it sounds like I could not, for example, create an auxilary varaible say sigma = f(c) and then couple that into HeatConduction by setting diffusion_coefficent to sigma?
I can create my own kernel, it sounds like it would have a the diffusion operator and then I would couple into that an external variable and this could be c, for example?
Thx!
John Sevic

is c really only a functioon of x, y z and t ?
if so then you can use:

a function (functionDiffusion)
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/FunctionDiffusion.html
an aux-variable
a material property (with HeatConduction)

They all work.
In general though, if c depends on a nonlinear variable you cannot use Functions or AuxVariables (unless you are not using AD for computing the Jacobian).

node.title: PF Coupling with Electrostatic Energy
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am doing PF of simulation of spinodal decomposition interacting with an electrostatic energy term, similar to the derivation of the weak form for SplitCHParsed.
How do I couple an electrostatic energy term to the CH equation? Is it an additional kernel or is there a clever way to add it to the SplitCHParsed kernel for free-energy density? It looks like I could specify the derivative and then add directly to the free-energy density?
Thank you.
John Sevic
I'd solve for the electrostatic potential using a poisson equation, and then couple that in the free energy expression

You can add the electrostatic term to the free energy. You free energy will then additionally depend on the electric potential, and this is taken care of by the derivative parsed materials. You electrostatics equation need to couple with the phase field, and that's the part you need to take care of.
The charge density in the poisson equation will be a function of the PF concentrations.

OK thanks let me show what I have so far and see if this makes sense.
My free-energy functional (immediately following eq. 2 on the P-F equation page) has the two usual terms, free-energy density and interface energy, and these are in eV. To this functional I add a term for coupling the electric potential energy, this term in eV is E_d = qcV, where q is charge and c is concentration variable and V is electric potential.
Now SplitCHParsed kernel calls DerivativeParsedMaterial, below is what I currently have without coupling to V.
Then in "expression" would I then add something like E_d = ev_JcV. Then DerivativeParsedMaterial automatically computes the partial derivative of E_d with respect to c as shown in the weak form table?
Thank you!
John Sevic
[./local_energy]
# Local free energy function in eV.
type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
property_name = f_loc
coupled_variables = 'c T V'
constant_names = 'a0  a2  a4  c1  c2  ev_J'
constant_expressions = '30.0 -4.00 2.80
0.30 0.80
1.6e-19 '
expression = 'ev_J*( (a0/2)*(0.0012*(T - 273) - c1)^2 -
  (a2/2)*(0.0012*(T - 273) - c2)*(4*c - 2)^2 -
  (a4/4)*(4*c - 2)^4 +
  0.25*(4*c - 2)^6 ) + INSERT POTENTIAL ENERGY TERM HERE'
derivative_order = 2
enable_jit = true

[../]

node.title: MOOSE Build and Test Problem
node.bodyText:
Hello,
So I have been trying to get started with MOOSE but keep running into problems (like my machine's compatibility with WSL) which I think I was able to resolve. My most recent problem that I can't overcome is that when I try to build MOOSE following the steps in Conda MOOSE Environment (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html) I get a fatal error. Please see below.
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 6

I tried running the command
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 4
and I got a successful build but then the test failed
cd ~/projects/moose/test
./run_tests -j 6
whether I ran -j 6 or -j 4. These are some examples of the failed tests.



Any advice would be really appreciated.

You were probably running out of memory while building. Lowering your -j count is probably what solved it. Roughly speaking, assume 2GB of RAM per -j.
As for the tests failing, you need to provide the actual failure. As detailed here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/troubleshooting.html#failingtests

@milljm Thank you for your response.
I will consider the -j count from here on out.

materials/derivative_material_interface.ad_analytic_derivatives/material_chaining:
materials/derivative_material_interface.ad_analytic_derivatives/material_chaining ........... FAILED (CSVDIFF)

Thank you.

The red ones are crashes (or simulation failing)
while the yellow is different results.
All these tests are tied to parsed expression for materials. These necessitate just in time compiling of the expression and can fail if the process running them does not have write access?
I havent seen them failing otherwise. Maybe @dschwen has seen more issues there
I tried following the steps on the troubleshooting site but I still get the errors. Not sure what is causing them.

Quick update:
I was able to build and Test MOOSE successfully using
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make -j 3
cd ~/projects/moose/test
./run_tests -j 3
However, when installing MOOSE, using the command
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
always created a problem whenever I tried using a moose command (even moose --help). The one that worked fine was
mamba create -n moose moose
which is the same one in the instructions for the Pre Built MOOSE (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/moose_conda_binary.html).
Thank you @milljm, @GiudGiud

moose-dev is for building moose from the source cloned from github (what you're trying to do up there)
moose like this is a package that includes a pre-built executable.
They fit different needs
Thank you very much for clarifying

I tried installing MOOSE again using
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
but the errors came back. So for some reason only the pre-built package
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
works. What could be causing this?

I am sorry but the following does not make sense, and I think you perhaps didn't mean to say it thus:

I tried installing MOOSE again using
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
but the errors came back. So for some reason only the pre-built package
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
works. What could be causing this?

So, doing this twice:

mamba create -n moose moose-dev

Will overwrite the "moose" Conda environment already existing when run the first time, and with the same packages (nothings changed). The following syntax explanation may help:
#                            the Conda package to install
#                        ///
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
#                ^^^ the name of the environment to create
Did you mean to say you tried:
mamba create -n moose moose-dev
And when that didn't work (can you paste what happened at this step?), you then installed the pre-built binary:
mamba create -n moose moose
and then this worked (can you expand on what you mean by this worked)?
The Conda package moose contains the binary, or executable you can use to run simple problems, instead of having to build your own binary from source. If you have need of building your own (if you wish to develop your own MOOSE based application), you instead want to install moose-dev. This package installs everything necessary for moose development.
You can have both, but you should not use the same Conda environment for both. Example of installing both:
mamba create --name moose_development moose-dev
mamab create --name moose_binary moose
With two Conda environments available, you can now:


I want to build my own special application:
mamba activate moose_development
cd /some/directory/my_app
make
./my_app-opt -i some_input.i


I want to just run a simple problem input file I have:
mamba activate moose_binary
moose -i some_input.i


I realize we make use of the same Conda environment name "moose" among our instructions. But this due to most of us only having need of one environment. You are free to create as many different Conda environment as you like!

I am sorry for the confusion I caused.
For the following, I am referring to the Conda MOOSE Environment website (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html).
What I mean is that I tried installing the moose-dev environment but testing it after the build returned errors. Then, I uninstalled the moose-dev environment and installed the moose (pre-built) environment. Testing the pre-built environment gave no errors.
I did not override one environment with the other.
I need the pre-built environment for now to get used to MOOSE and then I will transfer to the developer environment. But I just want to make sure that I can install the developer one without issues.
Thank you.

By not naming it something else, you do in fact, overwrite it. But regardless it is a harmless operation. Which ever one you last did, is the one in effect.
I see, so the environment with moose-dev is failing with 4 broken tests, and the environment with moose, is passing. Well I don't see that we are skipping those tests when run as a relocatable (the moose binary). So I am unsure as to why they are the only 4 failing.
Honestly, with so few failures you should not let that stop you from proceeding onward.
I take it, this is on a WSL machine, using Ubuntu 20.04? Or is it 22.04 now? I would like to try and reproduce the error.

Sounds good. I will move forward for now and I hope that I don't have problems running examples or following the tutorials.
It is on a WSL machine. Ubuntu 22.04 was installed when following the steps on the installation website.
Thank you so much for all your help!

node.title: Restarting from my restart file
node.bodyText:
Dear moose experts
I am a new user of MOOSE. I am trying to use a restarting command to start my simulation from the previous time steps.
restart_file_base = out_cp/LATEST
checkpoint = true
it's showing that the simulation started from the previous time steps (1st image) but in the printing value it's showing that it is started from the beginning again. Could you please help me regarding these issues.

Hello
the value of the start-time is determined by the input file, not the restart file iirc. A recover instead of a restart would use the checkpoint time
You ll want to change the start time in the executioner
Guillaume

Thank you for your kind reply. What should I do now? Actually, I want to restart my file from the previous time steps (i.e., time step:3). Should I change the starting time in the executioner? For example, if my code run 30 minutes initially and passed 3-time steps then should I use the 30 minutes as the staring time to restart my simulation from the time step 3.

If you specify the LATEST in the restart file base parameter of the problem, you are restarting from the latest step, which is 3 right?
When it says "Using ..." it s actually loading that file into each variable.
If you want the output to say time = 30min on that first step (in the console log), then you just need to change the start_time to make that happen

Yes, it shows that it is starting from time step 3 but in the printing output it is showing that it is started from time step zero (image-2). How can I modify the input file that my printing output will show that it is started from the time step 3?
you can change the start_time in the Executioner block to change the time step output

node.title: Restart and Recover Segmentation Fault when Mesh is Modified
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have tried using restart and recover on a simulation where I modified the mesh in the middle of the simulation by using CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier.
I get a segmentation fault when I try to do so. It says PID 5709, exit code 9, Segmentation Fault (signal 11). When I try to recover on an earlier checkpoint before the mesh is modified, it works.
Is there any way around this problem?
Thanks,
Cameron

Hello
We are in the midst of reworking this system, it should be more resilient to that soon.
For now you can try to use the SolutionUserObject / SolutionAux to restart instead. SolutionUserObject will be more capable of handling domain changes.
Guillaume

Good to hear that it will be reworked soon.
Is there a way to get SolutionUserObject / SolutionAux to import a stateful material property from a previous simulation?

ah no I dont think so.
@loganharbour we have no alternative than Checkpoint for stateful matprop right now do we?
No, we don't. And that likely will not change

This problem may be related to #22330. If you are moving elements around from a subdomain that had variables to another that doesn't have those same variables.

We are in the midst of reworking this system, it should be more resilient to that soon.

I don't think this particular problem will be fixed, but I think there may be an error that get's thrown instead of segfaulting.
@loganharbour  There is a MWE in that issue.

I can try to make some sense of a backtrace if you can get us one.
See https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html for more information. Once you've set a breakpoint, ran, and it has crashed, share the result of running bt in the debugger.
If you have an input that you're willing to share, I might be able to take a look there as well.

I'll work on recreating the problem in a minimal input file and get that to you soon.
I tried debugging on my own but I couldn't get any good information out of it.

ah forgot to pitch in earlier.
We are down for the backtrace, but at this point I believe the way forward is with a SolutionUserObject and SOlutionIC/Aux to set variables
this will enable non-matching meshes

node.title: volumetric locking correction for TET10
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose Community,
I have tried to activate the option "volumetric_locking_correction" (within [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]) for a mesh that consists exclusively of TET10 elements. Here I get the following error message from Moose:
"Volumetric locking correction should not be used for higher-order elements."
I would have assumed that TET10 elements are suitable for this correction. Do I have a misunderstanding?

TET10 is second order (4 vertex nodes + 6 mid-edge nodes we use for the additional dofs)
@recuero @roystgnr for the meat of the question

I'm more of a fluids guy than an elasticity guy, but I'd have assumed that Tet10 elements were suitable for the correction - https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/VolumetricLocking.html shows it being applied at the weak formulation level, so whatever sins it commits ought to be somewhat element-independent.  At least in the fluids world the best stabilization schemes don't actually hurt anything when they're used on spaces for which they're superfluous.  I'd guess it wasn't a necessary correction on Tet10 ... but http://solidmechanics.org/Text/Chapter8_6/Chapter8_6.php talks about using reduced integration (the other popular way to avoid locking here) on Tet10, so maybe I guessed wrong?

I doubt there's volumetric locking for second order TETs (or TRI in 2D). But it's been a long time since I last looked this problem. There is a traditional Cook's membrane problem to verify whether there's locking: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/VolumetricLocking.html
The reason for the error "Volumetric locking correction should not be used for higher-order elements." must be that someone tested higher-order elements and observed that no B-bar stabilization is needed. If you are interested, please feel free to try the Cook's membrane with second order TRI6. I am interested in your findings.
Shear locking though, is a different problem and we don't currently have a good way of stabilizing it.

Dear all,
please find below a small test model where two "plates" made of TET10 elements get bend by a point load. One plate is coarsly meshed. The other one consists of a very fine mesh. In case of PoissonsRatio=nu=0.3 the max displacement of both plates are in good agreement. For nu=0.49 the coarsly meshed plate reacts a lot stiffer.
A screenshot for nu=0.3 of both "plates" made from TET10 (max disp z of both plates is ca. 1.6m - color scale 0.0 - 1.6):

A screenshot for nu=0.49 of both "plates" made from TET10 (the coarsly meshed plate reacts stiffer - color scale 1.25-1.4):

Disclaimer: I'm not sure if volumetric locking is causing this - or shear locking. It is currently unclear to me how to distinguish these two effects. The idea was to find out using the moose option mentioned above.
The corresponding mesh file (please remove the ".txt")
PlateBender - OnlyVolumes.msh.txt
The input file (for nu=0.49):
# testing plate bending

# Model Units
modelunit_length = 'm'
modelunit_time   = 's'
modelunit_mass = 'kg' # Mg = tons; Gg = kilotons
modelunit_force  = ${raw ${modelunit_mass} * ${modelunit_length} / ${modelunit_time} ^ 2}
modelunit_pressure = ${raw ${modelunit_force} / ${modelunit_length} ^ 2}
#modelunit_acceleration = ${raw ${modelunit_length} / ${modelunit_time} ^ 2}
#modelunit_density = ${raw ${modelunit_mass} / ${modelunit_length} ^ 3}

[Mesh]
  [File]
    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = "PlateBender-OnlyVolumes.msh"
    #show_info = true
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  large_kinematics = false
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    new_system = true                     # TRUE to use the new lagrangian kernel system
    formulation = total                   # controlling if the UPDATED or TOTAL Lagrangian formulation is used (default is TOTAL)
    strain = small                        # FINITE or SMALL kinematic formulations
    #volumetric_locking_correction = true

    add_variables = true

    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz stress_yy stress_yz stress_zz '
                      #'max_principal_stress mid_principal_stress min_principal_stress '
  []
[]

# ===== Boundary Conditions =====
XMinSurfaces = 'SrfVolumeL1_XMinA_1 SrfVolumeL1_XMinB_1 SrfVolumeL2_XMinA_1 SrfVolumeL2_XMinB_1'
[BCs]

  [./BoundaryZMin_DispX]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = ${XMinSurfaces}
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []

  [./BoundaryZMin_DispY]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = ${XMinSurfaces}
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [./BoundaryZMin_DispZ]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = ${XMinSurfaces}
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
  []

[]

pointLoad = ${units 100 kN -> ${modelunit_force}}

[Functions]
  [./PointLoad]
    type = ParsedFunction
    symbol_names  = 'pointLoad'
    symbol_values = '${pointLoad}'
    expression = 'pointLoad * t'
  []
[]

[DiracKernels]

  [./point_source1]
    type = FunctionDiracSource
    variable = disp_z
    function = PointLoad
    point = '+2.0 +0.0 +0.0'
    #point_not_found_behavior = ERROR
  []

  [./point_source2]
    type = FunctionDiracSource
    variable = disp_z
    function = PointLoad
    point = '+2.0 -5.0 +0.0'
    #point_not_found_behavior = ERROR
  []

[]

volPlates = 'VolVolumeL2A_1 VolVolumeL2B_1 VolVolumeL1A_1 VolVolumeL1B_1'
[Materials]

  [./volPlates_elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    block = ${volPlates}
    youngs_modulus = ${units 1000E3 kN/m^2 -> ${modelunit_pressure}}
    poissons_ratio = 0.49
  []

  [./volPlates_stress]
    type = ComputeLagrangianWrappedStress
    block = ${volPlates}
  []

  [./volPlates_stress_base]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    block = ${volPlates}
  []

[]

[Executioner]
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 1.0
  dt = 1.0

  type = Transient
  #automatic_scaling = true
  #verbose = true
  
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = ' lu       mumps'
  
  nl_abs_tol = 1E-3
  #nl_rel_tol = 1E-12
  nl_max_its = 400
  
  l_tol = 1E-3
  l_max_its = 200
[]

[Outputs]
  perf_graph = true
  exodus = true
[]
